question: Question_03
statement:
Let $\displaystyle z=f(x,y)$, where $\displaystyle f(x,y)$ has
continuous second order partial derivatives, and

\begin{align*}
x&=2t^2, & y&=t^3, & & \\
f_x(2,1)&=5, & f_y(2,1)&=-2, & & \\
f_{xx}(2,1)&=2, & f_{xy}(2,1)&=1, & f_{yy}(2,1)&=-4\end{align*}

Find $\frac{\textrm{d}^2z}{\textrm{d}t^2}$ when \emph{t=1}.
sols:
First we evaluate the first derivative of z with respect to t using the
multivariable chain rule.

\begin{align*}
\frac{dz}{dt} &= f_{x}\frac{dx}{dt} + f_{y}\frac{dy}{dt}
&= f_{x}\cdot 4t + f_{y}\cdot 3t^{2}\end{align*} We then take the next derivative of z by taking the
derivative with respect to t of the above result, using the
multivariable chain rule again as well as the product rule.

\begin{align*}
\frac{d^{2}z}{dt^{2}} &= \frac{d}{dt}\left(f_{x}\cdot 4t + f_{y}\cdot 3t^{2}\right) \\
&= 4t(f_{xx}\cdot 4t + f_{xy}\cdot 3t^{2}) + 4f_{x} + 3t^{2}(f_{yx}\cdot 4t + f_{yy} 3t^{2}) + 6t \cdot f_{y}\end{align*} Next, we recognize that if t = 1, then (x,y) = (2,1).
Thus, we can use the information given in the question about the partial
derivatives of f to evaluate $d^{2}z/dt^{2}$ at t = 1:

\begin{align*}
\frac{d^{2}z}{dt^{2}} &= 4t(f_{xx}\cdot 4t + f_{xy}\cdot 3t^{2}) + 4f_{x} + 3t^{2}(f_{yx}\cdot 4t + f_{yy} 3t^{2}) + 6t \cdot f_{y} \\
\frac{d^{2}z}{dt^{2}}\Big\vert_{t = 1} &= 4(2(4) + 3) + 4(5) + 3(4 - 4(3)) + 6(-2) \\
&= 4(11) + 20 + 3(-8) - 12 = 28\end{align*} Therefore,
${\color{blue} \frac{d^{2}z}{dt^{2}}\Big\vert_{t = 1} =28}.$
hints:
After applying the multivariable chain rule to \emph{$f$} once, you will
need to apply it again to \emph{d$f$/dt} since the partial derivatives of
\emph{$f$} are also functions of \emph{x}, \emph{y}.

You will also need the product rule.
